HE summer twilight falling softly around the old Lee homestead was silently shutting up the flowers th at I he morning sun had kissed into fill bloom, and toucing- he tender green leaves of the maples shading the iOl-c 3 i dindows with a slight suspicion of gloom. PeacefI the light settled down over the harvest hills, until thetl 6 -*o6 - ands near the south meadow were lost in a -an ountla Cif - - hadows. But the inmates of the Lee farm-house-iia s Prown, angular, old-fashioned structure-gave lIt*h --g3 o the quiet adiu of the sun; for, as it is to a^ll Iwft ^3 he slow falling of the midsummer night was al V! tour with the Lee family-the hour when i M hores are to be disposed of, and the'afternofon; -^ m:+i roken by the bustling duties of-supper-time. - --; ^ Mrs. Lee was a perfect embodiment of the truee I fsetier- life, and knew how to economize both time and lt-or ,it er multiplicity of domestic cares. In the-mi-idsit -of -he- reatest hurry, brisk little Ruth Lee never Aei f4li ered in manner, discouraged in temper, nor ja bi 31o t r , ut, ever gentle and cheerful, her patient, lovig i e sac- S ified the arduous toil of every-day existencg Hi:- * 8 -w-H
vaded every-nook and corner of her pleasant home. It was a clear evening in August, twenty-five years ago, that we introduce the reader to this Ohio homestead, and its broad-shouldered, brawny-handed owner, David Lee. The old weather-embrowned home and sturdy farmer were the' pride and boast of the little village -of Alden. David, for his thrift, industry, and superior ideas of farming, was con- sidered as authority among his neighbors on the important sbibjects of stock-raising, subsoiling, draining, irrigating, enriching land, and the like. His farm was unanimously -onceded to be among the best in the State; his fine stock could safely challenge the best that grazed in Ohio's rich valleys, and his genial, brown-eyed wife was loved by every one on whom their kindly light had shone. On^bhis4nPgust evening the last cow of ten had been milked, and Hetty Smith - Mrs. Lee's maid-of-all-work, or --"help," as she was usually designated by her sprightly le mistress-was busy in the dairy, actively engaged in straini -the milk into the brightest of pans from the 4 b$45 Nof pails. Not one of your modern strainers, but , 1g4 nariow piece of linen, white as snow, dexterously 1 hidel by Hetty's experienced hands tight across one-half the pai, answered the purpose admirably. With a quick rush e milk, warm and foaming, splashed through the filtering- ,lot. h into the burnished pans one after another, until the long row was filled and carefully set to "rise." Iletty plumed herself greatly on her butter and cheese- ;.kng, not permitting even her mistress within the sacred H Princts of-the dairy, save as an -applauding spectator. hie was extremely particular regarding the scalding and rnsig of her "milk things," and would allow no ordinary dishcloth or, wiper to come in contact with the dazzling * duty of her cherished pans and pails, strainers and creami- pots Hetty's power was supreme in the butter region, ilV she clattered in the dairy, Mrs Lee flitted noiselessy from kitchen to pantry, intent on arranging the supper- table, occasionally stopping in her light walk-you would guess without being told, that it was a mother's heart that modulated the soft footfalls-to peep into the little willow cradle where slumbered her fair-haired baby. Not the first baby - ah! no; little Vida was the fourth. But the others slept out in the grave-yard, silent and still, cradled' in tiny coffins, and covered by the summer daisies. Mrs. Lee had tenderly laid her little ones from her arms into the grave, trusting in God that it wasbest; and now, Vida, the eight-months old darling, was the only one left of the - four rosy babies that came amid joy and blessings to brighten the old Lee farm-house. Three little mounds on the hillside; three little tablets recording the briefness of three little lives - that was all. But they left thehome- stead desolate and the willow cradle empty. After a time another came, and the mother called her Vida, the girl namesake of the father. Farmer Lee poohed and pishedl ' the idea at first; but his wife insisted, and so, wetly. pleased, he acquiesced, although protesting that whWi:dt had to do with his plain name of David was more thi he.:!.- could tell. But little Ruth silenced him by impartim: X with a convincing kiss on his ruddy cheek, which she h-i to stand on tiptoe to reach, that both names meant be, and were bhe dearest in the world to her. Where bluff Farmer Lee patted her brown hair, and declareT Ruth was tls- dearest name of all others to him; but little Ruth lay buried, the other should have her wayi so the blue-eyed infant, with many hopes and 'fea "4 baptized Vida Lee. On this particular evening supper was muh lat&e usual, for it was the last day of hayin, a little importance in the quiet routine of farmiri' Li Ihad determined to finish that day, and c Orul y : informed his pretty helpmate at dinner "tlt ill retty,f
wouldiwork till moonrise, but that the last load- should be safe in the barn," winding up his decision with a cheery- X "So, my wife, you must get along without Thad, for once." The obliging wife assured David that she would willingly do so, and that is how Hetty was forced to bring up the cows and milk without the assistance of the boy designated rather vaguely by Mr. Lee as "Thad." While Mrs. Lee tripped to and fro, loading the table with all sorts of good things to appease the substantial ap- petites of those awaiting its wholesome plenty, the last huge load came slowly through the dusk, the odorous hay almost hiding the big brown oxen, whose wearily drooping heads and dragging steps told that they had had an unusually busy day. The just rising harvestnoon shone calmly down on the tired men and cattle, lighting up the dew-wet grass, through which millions oftireflies glowed and sparkled" like tiny stars in (an emerald sky. Behind the cart came X Farmer Lee, in shirt-sleeves and broad-brimmed straw hat, , carrying a rake and pitchfork on his shoulder, and in his hand the large stone water-jug. ^"'Baker!" he called lustily to one of the hands in dvance of the rest, "you had better get the steers up right i 4way; the unruly brutes will be in the corn before morn- ing. Put them in the barn-yard, and then come to supper. i; guess Thad can get in the load alone." So saying, David vaulted over the garden fence, and made for the htdhen. - *I 8ijaker promptl started after the unruly steers, and the yuthful Thad, -who was driving the brown oxen, made for 4 e barn, whose wide doors stood, open, waiting to receive thljast load into its alreadyull bosom. Th-Je boy walked thoughtfully beside the cattle, medita- -elyc'hewing the stem of a fragrant red clover, until the , de phorns of the oxen were almost entering the barn door, when he quickened his pace, and shouted encouragingly, "Come on, Bright! haw. up, gee! come along in with it!!' . by voice and gesture urging the obedient cattle to their utmost. The strong animals meekly responded to his rapid words, and pulled with alltheir great strength. In a -moment they were standing quietly in the middle of the barn floor, their puffing breath and heaving sides telling plainly that they had done their very best. Thad dropped his whip, and in a second the little fingers had detached the heavy cart tongue. No sooner did it strike the floor than both oxen started for the yard. The lad quickly fol lowed, removed the encumbering yoke, and turned their willing heads in the direction of the south pasture. Then ' he made all haste to the kitchen pump. After refreshing himself by a vigorous wash, he leisurely proceeded to brush : the hay-seeds from his thick auburn hair, and don a slimpsy 3 /i: linen coat, when he was ready for supper. Despite that thei boy looked tired and heated, his face possessed a sort of grave beauty that made one forget the coarse, unbleached cotton ii shirt, stained by grass-cutting and perspiration into a many- colored garment, the collarless neck, and ungainly shoes. Although he was very hungry, the lad stopped to kiss baby 'Vida, who, now wide awake, was industriously staring at- ^ the candle flickering on the mantel. After setting her little -- ladyship bolt upright in her cradle, and securing her ease . and safety by propping her up with as many pillows asa S j he could find, he passed on to the supper awaiting i thel:: kitchen. ' After supper, Thad sat down in his old place onti, front-door steps, and, resting his elbows on his kt-ee:- looked absently out into the night. He was a mere bc -f years, scarcely thirteen, possessing a thoughtful minde1 Ha a severe, reserved manner,-in strange contrast with his ' -b; ish appearance, that always impressed one with. the id that he was different from other children of his age. Sitting there in the doorway, with his dew-moisteni i-
locks pushed back from the sunburned brow, and his face still with inward thought, a lover of phrenology .would have said that the finely developed head of Thaddeus Rug- gles, Farmer Lee's bound-boy, contained a brain- of rare promise, and the ability to do great things when the boy became a man, and the world before him,in which to win a place. ,4Forensic genius was stamped on the high, open forehead. Oratorical power slumbered in the full auburn brown eyes, andhe calm, unsmiling mouth seemed formed to utter the gravest truths. Vain flight of fancy! for Thaddeus Ruggles was the son of a drunkard, born' amid vice and poverty so deep that it still lingered a bitter memory in his young soul. The grand intellect, destined oflieaven for great and noble purposes, was cradled in rags. The first cry of the richly gifted babe wailed out amid the cheerless gloom of a stormy winter's night. The morning found a helpless infant and a dead mother in the Ruggles shanty. The poor -house received the child, and the earth took to its frozen'bosom the starved, heart-broken i mother. Two years later, the wretched father died the ; drunkard's horrible death, and little Thad, the pet of the. ::; ppor-house, was indeed an orphan. :One"4ay, while passing the alms-house, David Lee - -huacl ed to catch a glimpse of the child's grave face, peep- as;g:; through.'the wide slats of the gate that marked the :..or iouse grounds. The bright, intelligent features'pleased i hrim, and he said mentally, "He is a smart little chap, - whosever child he is.: I vow I ll take him home to Ruth. i H er'heart; ache for the boy she buried two months Sago; - so I I :,1her this little; castaway. Women o( her I i^fo rt ing suc tJhings." ] ;.:;0th,:;si;:was to aCt, with Mr. Le&. Accordingly he i. 1i i h bf y roadsger'i:and, in his enet etic way, made ls;i'"ire known toethe Superintendent o6'the. institution, ;who r:eadily agreed-toi' proposals:. A*few old paupers w *,ea ' ' 'g * , , sa whimpered dismally when they found that little Thad was going away forever, and kissed him with their withered lips, and wrinkled cheeks wet with their sorrowing tears; for the child had been cared for by the old hands that tried to bless and caress him in palsied trembling ere he went i from among them to a harder home, perhaps, and a colder care. No one paid any heed to their grief, however, and in twenty minutes the necessary papers were made Out, and little Thad Ruggles, then only five years old, was lawfully bound to David Lee until he was twenty-one. Mrs. Lee kindly welcomed the motherless child of the poor-house, who would sit at her feet while she sewed, with his large, reddish-brown eyes intent on her face, for hours : it a time, without changing his attitude or speaking a word -so still and mute that his child-gaze became strangely painful to Ruth, who would throw aside her work and take ? aim in her lap just to see if the earnest mouth would smile back a reward for the kiss she gave it. But in vain her i Caresses. Before its birth the child's nature had been bap- :ized in its mother's grief and tears. She had sobbed out -I ler life trying to shield this grave-faced boy from the cold ' hat was chilling her heart's blood. From his dead mother .S Chad had inherited his soft auburn hair and eyes, Is that habitual look of sadness which gave Ruth such- quiet, and made her wish that he would laugh and shoti like other little boys of his age. Thaddeus never cared for play, and accepted work, w i i" ie was old enough to be of use, as a necessity that counl lot be avoided. He was always willing to do anything equired of him, cheerful and even in temper. Seldom . angry, never gay, but always thoughtful, he plodded through he many tasks set for him unmurmuringly, content that , is hands should labor, though. his mind-was perpetually randering after that which the farm could not give. Thaddeus worked hard, as all the Lee-'household id. -: - ' ' .( ' i
WH'O WAS SHE? Ruth was a kind mother to him, and his food and clothing were as good as that of his indulgent master. Mr. Lee sent him to school each winter, and generously provided him with books, that he might acquire a good education, thus in a measure fitting him for a useful life. Thaddeus, recalling the bitter memory of his lowly birth and the miserable degradation of his poor-house existence, would find his eyes filling with grateful tears when contrast- ing the past with the present. He often reproached him- self for lack of enthusiasm regarding his master's cherished farm plans, and once shyly intimated as much to Mr. Lee. : But the farmer only laughed, and said, good-naturedly, "Stick to your books, Thad, my boy; I see your mind runs X that way. Dig all you can out of sheepskin, and I'll grub in the soil." Thad did stick to his books, and studied i until the thoughtful eyes grew still more thoughtful, and the serious mouth more silent in its earnestness. - ? ,; .,:'";-1:tT'rT-.i WHO WAS SHE 21a CHAPTER II. WHO WAS SHEa? X FOl TOR more than an hour Thad had been sitting mothon- less on the door-stone, and might have sat there all : night had not Ruth's gentle voice interrupted his musings. "i:' Come, Thad, you have worked very hard to -day, and ! the nights are short. Go to bed now and rest, for it will ? soon be to-morrow." II M "Yes, mother," (he always called the little woman mo- ; ther;) and, instantly rising, he turned to go, but paused X on hearing the latch of the garden gate rise and fall as if ' a weak hand had tried in vain to open it. Rove, the great I lumbering Newfoundland, sleeping near by in the grass, caught the faint sound, and lifted his head with a low, warning growl. ..... "Did you not hear the latch lift, Thad?" asked Mrs. Lee, peering out in the moonlight. "Hettie is in the : kitchen, and father's been in bed an hour, so it can't be A:d either of them. It is so dark under the maples that one t*:. can't see anything, if anything were there." "I thought I heard some one at the gate, but I guess H i as mistaken," replied Thad. But, as he spoke, again came the faint click of the latch, this time followed by a 's low groan. Rove started up with a furious bark, and made a dash for the gate. "Hush, Rove!" commanded Thad, 5 :as he flew after him. In a moment the boy was heard cry- ::! ing hurriedly: "Oh, mother, come quick! It is a woman, and she has fainted- dead, perhaps. Oh, do come quick and help ' er!.in , - ' ": ' ; Mrs. Lee instantly obeyed the excited voice, and was -
22 WHO WAS SHE? X soon beside the prostrate woman, vigorously chafing the cold hands and white temples of the stranger, and giving vent to softly uttered words of pity. "Poor, young thing! what a miserable plight to be in. See, she has dropped her bundle - put it under her head, Thad, and then run for Hetty. She must be got into the house as soon as possible." - -ad caught up the bundle as directed, but came near I l:ting it fall again, so great was his astonishment on feel- ting something stir within. hi: "Bundle!" he cried, in amazement; "do you call this a #' bundle? Why, mother, it's alive; I can feel it kick; it's ' a baby - a warm, breathing baby." '"Oh, goodness!" gasped little Ruth, all in a flutter, snatching the kicking bundle from the wondering Thad with feminine dexterity. ? '& "A baby! Bless me, so it is! Oh, dear, dear -call A:^ EHetty. We must not let the poor, senseless mother die out ::t here in the night." Thad rushed to the kitchen, and nearly frightened placid i:i;- Hetty out of her wits by blurting out in a breathless i:': manner: !:! "There is a woman with a baby, lying dead-I guess she l; :is dead-at the gate." A -Hetty, shocked beyond words, and forgetful of her cool- ing dish-water, threw her apron over her head and ran to the aid of her mistress. - Mercy!" she cried, bending compassionately over 'the motionless figure, and placing her hard hand on the. seem- - i? inglypulseless breast. "Mercyon us! Who is she? She 1i? '^ don't belong in these parts, that 's certain. Who in the world can she be? Deary me, how white her face is! Thank 'y- heaven, her heart, beats yet. I reckon, Mrs. Lee, she has ,r only fainted. Tired out, and famished beside- that's what : nails her. Bread and butter will bring her around all right.? "I hope so," returned Ruth, tearfully. "But- God help. us, it is a pitiful sight." IAh, yes; it was a pitiful sight! Heaven's summer stars i never looked down on a sadder picture than that of the woman who lay rigidly still and white as marble under the X maples. Her long, bright hair, trailing over the damp ai grass, mingled its fairness with the dust of earth before it I had known the touch of death. Fitful rays of moonlight : flickered through the thick lqaves and lit up the poor, pale, ai pinched face, with its closed eyes and chill brow, ghastly ! E white in its stillness. ;: k"Oh, God help her!" sighed Mrs. Lee, as Thaddeus and l Hetty lifted the frail form and silently bore her alongthe ri grassy garden path to the house, Ruth following with the- % child sound asleep in her motherly arms. Carefully ;i depositing it in Vida's cradle, she turned to assist in- placing the stranger on the green-covered sitting-room lounge, when every means was employed to restore the poor r creature to consciousness. At last their efforts were suc- cessful, and she slowly opened a pair of mournful gray eyes in blank bewilderment at the trio of strange faces ij bending pityingly above her. "Who are you all?" shetasked, striving to sit up. - c "We are friends," answered Ruth, gently; " and you are safe from the night dews. But you look ill; have you travelled far?" - i u "I am very weary, and have travelled a long, long way, and H-" The poor thing hesitated and turned awity her head. But thought of the fountain that was perishing for want of bodily sustenance encouraged her to speak, and for her child's sake she conquered her rising pride, and added, in a pitiful whisper, "And I am very hungry." 'Thad waited to hear no more, but bounded for the pan- try as if life depended on his reaching it in a second. Hetty, anxiously called after him:
"I guess you will find the tea hot yet, Thad; I left the ,ot on the stove, and the fire ain't out." Thaddeus soon returned with food enough to satisfy the ,ppetite of a dozen hungry women. The tea provred pass- Ibly hot, and the famished stranger swallowed a cupful at I:n , single draught. She had fasted for two days, and ate ? ike one starving. ^ :B Suddenly she dropped the empty cup and sprang to her eet. Clasping her hands in a spasm of anguish, she cried vildly, "Oh, my baby; where is my baby? Oh! God, I j lave lost my child! I must find my child!"Frantic with g his new grief, she was about to rush out in sarch of her , ost infant, when Hetty stopped her by taking her by the jmr-and pointing toward the cradle. : "Don't distress yourself; the baby is all right, and sleep- ng like a top." :! In the general excitement the little one had been forgot- en, but now everybody seemed bent on giving it the utmost Lttention; and the three females simultaneously made a ;rasp at the softly breathing and heretofore neglected bun- be stowed away in the cradle. Mrs. Lee got the start, and succeeded in holding entire ssession of the unconscious infant. Tired and exhausted, he mother sank back on the sofa, with the great, thankful ears silently dropping through her fingers, content to rest WoI ithat her child was safe. -Hetty stood near in breathless expectation, while her nistress removed the baby's wrappings, revealing the blackS- ingleted head of a. mite of a baby, apparently some Asix nonths old. The blackest eyes ever seen quickly opened, hming like two stars from beneath their dark, heavily? ringed lids. - "Oh, what a baby!" exclaimed Thad, starting back in surprise*, "Such eyes for an atom like that I Why, I can cover its whole face with the palm of my hdind. It's all hair and eyes; just look at them twinkle."' "And they snapped openp,bright as diamonds, without a drowsy look in them," added Hetty, admiringly. "So big and black and solemn! I never before saw so odd and- mowing an expression in a baby's eyes ;.and then that lead of curls might belong to a girl of five." "Yes; but it's a singularly lovely child, withal," said Ruth, stooping to kiss its red, smiling mouth. The little ips curled angrily at the light touch, and a frown gathered n the tiny brow. Kicking out a rebellious foot, and toss- ig up her little doubled fists, she gave vent to a very ecided cry of displeasure. Baby had no mind to be criti- ised so freely, waif though she was, and with all her ower of lungs resented the indignity put upon her help- 1ssness. In vain Mrs. Lee essayed to soothe the vigorously protest- g atom in her lap. She only yelled the harder. "Give her to me," said a weak voice from the sofa; and uth gladly handed over her spunky little charge. l The moment the gypsy head found itself pillowed on the ! )ther's bosom a profound silence ensued, and the spacrki ig black eyes shone victoriously n the assembled group ' would-be soothers. ..- "Will you keep us to-night?" went on the weak voice, mulous with emotion. "For this innocent babe's sake annot die in the street. I am a stranger in a strange : ' id, poor and friendless. You look kind and good. Have y on the unfortunate, and give us shelter from the 56 Certainly," replied Ruth. "We never turn away even a undeserving needy who come to our door, much -ess al therwith a helpless infant in her arms. Your face beais sad impress of sorrow and tears, but you look Hke one - , ' ' . -*?!
26 WJHO WAS SHE? who has kept God in the midst of great trouble, and a woman's purity in the face of much suffering." Hetty wiped a. tear from hier eye, and, glancing from the ringless finger of the stranger to the dark head of the elf- like child, sighed doubtingly. The woman caught the doubting glance of Hetty's: honest eyes, and, looking down at the small lineaments resting in her lap, said, in ap explanatory tone: 'She resemble her father --just his hair and eyes and lool Again the ready tears came stealing down the pale cheeks, but she hastily put up a trembling hand to wipe them away, for the hot drops falling on baby's little face made her angry, and sudden ominous kicks warned the sad mother to desist a further baptism of tears. Evidently the child's father recalled bitter memories of the past- memories that had blighted this sorrowful, gray-eyed woman's life id its spring-time, and left her a wanderer, without home 'r kindred. Something of the kind was doubtless passing through Hetty's-active mind, for she thought: t ' Some hanlsome scamp has been the poor thing's ruin, and this witchb'of a baby is all his deceitful love was worth. His eyes and hair and that look coot her everything, and him-nothing." - In the midst of Hetty's kindling wrath a new auditor appeared on the scene. No less a personage than the master of the house, in a decidedly scant night-toilet, and Wearing- an exceedingly surprised expression on his ruddy phiz. "What in the world are you all up so late for?" he inquired, modestly holding the bed-room door as close as he possibly could, with half his inquiring liead thrust through the aperture. "Come, Ruth," he continued, some- what impatienty. "Come, wife; Davie' (he had fallen into' the habit of calling little Vida Davie) "is squirming w N O WAS SHE? 2t like an eel, and, Lord knows, I am tired enough without-. Good heavens! what does this mean?" cried the master, thrusting his head through the partially open door, regard- less of the briefness of his garments, on beholding the extraordinary company seated in his sitting-room at that unseemly hour. Thad was standing dejectedly by the mantel, while Hetty sat bolt upright, with her arms severely folded, in the grim- mest of silence. She had settled it in her own mind relas* tive to the "handsome scamp," and was not to be easily softened. ANY one who had seen the Lee homestead fifteen years before, could scarcely believe that it was the same dwelling. The old house remained just the same, but a great renovation had taken place within. The-metamor- phosis was not so general in the sitting-room and upper regions, but in the parlor it was triumphant. -There the - plain, clumsy furniture had given way entirely. The old- fashioned chairs and ponderous sofa had been superseded by light, modern upholstery, and the once sacred,' best things " were ingeniously scattered, never to stand aWn in rigid pomp in the best room. !; - - Many elegant feminine trifles, arranged in nooksimd, : :

The new reign brought them, as well as the velvet-voiced canary, singing in h's gilded cage, hop- ping from perch to seed-cup, with a twittering song that merged into a clear warble when his young mistress came to give him a gay good-day. Then there was any number of cunningly made tidies, mats, and the like. Wax flowers and burr frames were also conspicuous, with ingenious bits of shell-work, and a marvel in the way of a sofa-pillow, made from infinitesimal scraps of silk of every conceivable color, nicely joined together in a square, and stuffed out as plump as a Christmas turkey. But all this was nothing *compared to the wonders wrought in the parlor. The homemade striped carpet had disappeared, and. now a pretty ingrain sprinkled its roses over the floor. Lace cur- tains had supplanted the common green-paper shades that used to be rolled up with a cotton string, finished with a glaring white tassel of Hetty's modest manufacture, which probably accounted for its scrimp and fuzzy appearance. And there in the corner, where Elinor Vale had lain through,- the holy time between death and the waiting grave,/stood a handsome rosewood piano. In speaking of this last extravagance, David had con- tentedly remarked: "Well, well; I am prosperous, and -can afford it. The girls, Lord bless 'em! begged it out of me; and then 'the carpet and chairs and curtains would n't do; and then the whitewashed walls and lumbering old sofa was no match; and as I'd not like a tumble-down old shed next to my new barn, I gave in. They trundled out the spinning-wheeland trundled in the piano. -It was kind o' tough to see the old thing go., But the girls must ad- vance with the times -things are different since -uth's day-and we can't expect it of the young folks; and it mightily pleases women to fix up in-doors. I'd affection for the stiff, grim old traps of sixty years ago, because they were familiar with my mother's face, and the pride she took in dusting and arranging them was touching. Citizens on whom he had vented his mischief were gray-headed grandfathers now, and boys he had whacked, tall, bewhiskered chaps, whom he privately thought he could thrash yet, in a rough- and-tiumble fight, such as had immortalized his youth.
